instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi guys.

I have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power. 

3v & 5V present created from <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.6v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> Triggers

I found that i'm missing <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> which comes from S0 Enables and i don't have voltage even from <RESISTOR>R1462</RESISTOR> and the resistor is fine 100K but it shows when measured on board 36.4k.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> i get3.3v on <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>. I tried to solder together pins 4 and 5 on <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> to get the voltage but still no power.

On <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> pin 6 i have 3.3v but also normally <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is missing. 

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
Any pulse at L7520?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> it's 0v and L7520 i don't have a o-scope but when trigger SMC bypass  no changes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> - 2.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 0v

I remeasured and re-soldering the SMC and i don't have 5 and 3v on coils but i get green and then orange light no power

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I got back the 3 and 5v there was a broken line near <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

Now i have:
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>  -  2.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>   - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>  - 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 1.05v"
Not good, need to fix it.
Check first <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> level?
Be sure to use original Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Post again all above mentioned signals.
Also check the 4 PCH's RTC signals.

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> must appear before pressing power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.4v at first but after some time drops to 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>  - 2.7v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>  - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>  - 3.4v then sometimes drops to 1v

The only place that shows heat on the thermal camera is <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> but the temperature is below 30

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 0v 
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3v

I bridged <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and got 3v and a fan spin and power on. I really don't know why <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>  was stuck

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I did change it before i assemble it :) Thanks for the help
